learning_outcomes.description: Articulate the role of functional foods and nutraceuticals as options to aid health.
Illustrate the role of functional foods and nutraceuticals and their associated health benefits.
Access the legislation governing functional foods and nutraceuticals.
Critically analyse and integrate information from various sources and effectively use appropriate information and communication technologies.
Interact effectively with others and work towards a common outcome.

assessments.weighting: <dd>30% Each Quiz contributes 15% towards the total weighting of 30% </dd>
assessments.task_description:
Quiz 1 will be based on lecture content from Weeks 1–2.

Quiz 2 will be based on lecture content from Weeks 5–6.

The quizzes will be conducted in-class and online via Blackboard during lecture hours. You will have 20 minutes to complete the quiz worth 15 marks in a single session, and only one attempt will be permitted. The quiz will include various questions: short answer, essay, problem-solving, fill-in-the-blank, and true-or-false. Bring your laptop fully charged.

Each quiz contributes 15% to your overall grade.

This assessment task evaluates students' abilities, skills and knowledge without the aid of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT). Students are advised that the use of AI or MT technologies to develop responses is strictly prohibited and may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

Students are responsible for ensuring a stable internet connection while undertaking an online test/quiz. This test will be taken on a UQ campus location with secure internet service.

Troubleshooting – if students experience any technical difficulties during the online test/quiz: 

  • Do not close the browser window. 
  • Seek assistance from the Course Coordinator during this in-class assessment first. Contact AskUs support.my.uq.edu.au/app/chat/chat_launch_lib – if the technical issue cannot be resolved, ask for a copy of the chat. 
  • Document the problem – if you receive an error message or similar, take a copy of the message, note the time/date of the problem, which web browser you used, exactly what you were doing at the time and any other relevant information. 
  • Email your course coordinator (copy in AGFS Admin – agriculture@enquire.uq.edu.au) with your documented evidence and a copy of the AskUs chat. Any delays in this communication being received may impact the advice that could be provided to you.
assessments.submission_guidelines: This assessment is submitted in class during a timetabled session, via Blackboard.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.assessment_title: Claim vs Evidence in Functional Foods Presentation
assessments.task_description:
Task overview

In groups of four, you will critically evaluate an allocated functional food product and compare it with three market substitutes to determine the single most suitable substitute. You will communicate your findings through a recorded PowerPoint presentation (Echo recording) submitted through an Assignment submission link in Blackboard. The steps to create a Echo Video are in this link https://elearning.uq.edu.au/student-guides-ultra/echovideo-ultra-student. Only one group member needs to submit the file, but the submission must include the allocated food product and the names of all group members.

Groups are self-selected and managed via Blackboard. Instructions on how to create or join a group in Blackboard will be provided in Week 1, and groups will be formed in Weeks 1–2. Students who do not have a group should use the Blackboard group tool and tutorial time to connect with others; teaching staff can assist with matching where possible. Students must be in a group by the end of Tutorial Session 2. Students who have not joined a group by this time will be allocated to a group.

Tutorial sessions will include structured time for group collaboration and progress checks; however, additional work outside class time may be required.


Task Details

1) Investigate the allocated product

Your analysis must include:

  • identification of the functional component(s) and their intended role in the product
  • summary of the proposed health benefit(s) and mechanism(s) (where relevant)
  • a dose/serving plausibility check using label/manufacturer information and credible sources
  • identification and justification of the single most critical functional component in the allocated product


2) Identify three substitutes (market products)

For each substitute, include:

  • product name/brand and intended function
  • key functional component(s)
  • relevant nutrition/ingredient information from label/manufacturer sources
  • brief justification for why it is a reasonable substitute


3) Select the best substitute

Compare the allocated product against the three substitutes using an evidence-based rationale. Your final selection must be justified using:

  • functional component equivalence (type/form/relevance)
  • strength of evidence supporting the claimed benefit(s)
  • dose/serving plausibility
  • overall formulation context (e.g., added sugar/sodium/saturated fat where relevant)

 

Presentation requirements (slides + recording)

Slides

  • 10–12 slides (excluding the reference slide if preferred)
  • Slides should be predominantly visual (tables/figures/icons), with minimal text
  • All figures, label images, and non-original content must be acknowledged on the relevant slide
  • Include in-slide citations and a reference slide (consistent style)

Your presentation must clearly include:

  • aim and identification of the allocated product + three substitutes
  • functional component comparison (concise and specific)
  • evidence summary and rationale (including a brief strength-of-evidence judgement with citations)
  • clear conclusion naming the best substitute and why


Recording and submission

  • Record your group presentation using Echo
  • Duration: 12 minutes (timed)
  • Submit the recording via the Turnitin submission link on Blackboard by the due date/time. Only one group member needs to upload the recorded presentation on behalf of the group.
  • Ensure audio is clear and slides are readable throughout the recording


Peer Assessment

  • Each student will evaluate the contribution of the other members to the poster and preparation for the presentation using the Peer Assessment form provided on Blackboard.
  • Peer assessment contributes to an individual's mark out of 10. Failure to submit the peer assessment form by the due date/time will result in 0/10 for the peer assessment component (individual mark).
  • Marks: Presentation = 30 marks (group mark); Peer assessment = 10 marks (individual mark).


Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use Artificial Intelligence (AI) and/or Machine Translation (MT) tools, successful completion of the assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which AI or MT will provide only limited support and guidance. 

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct. 

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission, independent of AI and MT tools. 

The use of AI or MT must be acknowledged appropriately. Please see the assessment guidelines in blackboard course site for specific instructions.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
The end of semester exam will be on-campus exam, students must attend in person. Have your UQ student ID card available for all your exams.

The exam consists of short answers/essays and extended essays on the lecture material and associated reading to test both knowledge and understanding of the topic. The lecture topics covered during the online quiz will not be included in the final exam.

The examination will assess the level of theoretical knowledge and understanding of:

  • The key functional components in different food groups
  • The key types and activities of the functional bioactive ingredients
  • The main health benefits of the functional bioactive ingredients and their mechanism of action
  • The manufacturing of the functional ingredients


This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(23 Feb - 31 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Lecture Series

  • This learning activity is delivered through a structured lecture series that introduces functional foods and nutraceuticals and applies key concepts across major food categories.
  • Lectures cover: Introduction to Functional Foods & Nutraceuticals; Functional Components in Milk (I–II); Regulatory Environment and Health Claims; Functional Components in Cereals (I–II); Functional Components in Fruits & Vegetables (I–II); Functional Components in Tea, Coffee & Cocoa, Herbs and Spices, Seafoods & Meat, and Microalgae.
  • Each lecture focuses on the bioactive components within the food group and how these relate to proposed health effects and the evidence base underpinning claims.
learning_activities.topic_description: Lecture Series This learning activity is delivered through a structured lecture series that introduces functional foods and nutraceuticals and applies key concepts across major food categories. Lectures cover: Introduction to Functional Foods & Nutraceuticals; Functional Components in Milk (I–II); Regulatory Environment and Health Claims; Functional Components in Cereals (I–II); Functional Components in Fruits & Vegetables (I–II); Functional Components in Tea, Coffee & Cocoa, Herbs and Spices, Seafoods & Meat, and Microalgae. Each lecture focuses on the bioactive components within the food group and how these relate to proposed health effects and the evidence base underpinning claims.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 2 To Week 11(02 Mar - 17 May)
learning_activities.topic:
Tutorial Series

Tutorials support the lecture series through guided, evidence-based application and assessment preparation. Tutorials are interactive sessions where students apply lecture concepts through discussion and structured activities. Students work in self-selected groups to explore an assigned functional component and analyse market products that contain it. Tutorials also include assessable group presentations (from Week 7), where each student explains their allocated product and demonstrates product-specific analysis using on-pack label information. Tutorial time is used for group planning, coordination, and applying evidence-based reasoning to product claims, with staff available to answer questions and provide feedback.
